channel.title: Ramah: Good News Feed
channel.description: Positive news stories from around the world, filtered by sentiment analysis

item.title: Top of the props: meet the unsung heroes behind the memorable objects in your favourite films
item.description: The red and blue pills in The Matrix.

item.title: From Bone Temple to Oscar hopefuls, here are January's best movies
item.description: As awards season heats up multiple Oscar hopefuls, such as Jafar Panahi's incendiary It Was Just an Accident and Richard Linklater's love letter to French film, are finally hitting Australian cinemas.

item.title: Rescue efforts underway after landslides hit New Zealand campground and house
item.description: Rescue efforts were underway on Thursday to find people buried in rubble after a landslide hit a campground in New Zealand.

item.title: Australian qualifier Maddison Inglis rides emotions to tense win but local hopes fade
item.description: Inspired qualifier Maddison Inglis has ridden an emotional rollercoaster in her first grand slam appearance in four years to book a spot in the Australian Open third round.

item.title: Novak Djokovic eases into third round with clinical win over Francesco Maestrelli at Australian Open – as it happened
item.description: Thank you for joining me again this afternoon to witness Novak Djokovic joining the other leading men in the third round of the Australian Open.

item.title: How positivity affects health, the rise of scabies and bovine intelligence – podcast
item.description: The Guardian’s science editor, Ian Sample, talks to Madeleine Finlay about three eye-catching science stories from the week, including a study that suggests positive thinking can boost immune response.

item.title: ‘We want to make jacket potatoes sexy again!’: how the humble spud became a fast food sensation
item.description: They were once a lunch option that inspired little excitement – but the jacket potato’s time has finally come.

item.title: Watch: Russian cosmonaut captures stunning aurora from space
item.description: Cosmonaut Sergey Kud-Sverchkov captured breathtaking views of aurora lights over Earth, seen from the International Space Station.

item.title: March for Australia admins encouraged people to join White Australia Party
item.description: An ABC NEWS Verify investigation has revealed that some of those involved behind the scenes of the March for Australia (MFA) anti-immigration protests previously tried to recruit people to the now disbanded Neo-Nazi White Australia Party.

item.title: Live: Qualifier keeps Australian women's tilt alive with thrilling second-round win
item.description: Qualifier Maddison Inglis reaches the third round with a tense victory over German veteran Laura Siegemund to remain the last local alive in the women's singles draw.

item.title: Some Britons wonder if the U.S. and U.K.'s 'special relationship' may end in divorce
item.description: Some people in Britain are asking what it would look like for their government to sever security and intelligence ties with its closest ally, the U.S.

item.title: Are 'passkeys' better than passwords? This security expert says yes
item.description: Has your phone been prompting you for months to log into certain sites with a "passkey"? Security writer Kim Key of PC Mag explains why you might want to ditch your passwords in favor of passkeys.

item.title: For 50 years, ABC Classic has connected music lovers across Australia
item.description: ABC Classic is turning 50 years young on Saturday January 24.

item.title: If your kid's asking for brands, your response could make a huge difference
item.description: Covering back-to-school expenses such as shoes and headphones can be daunting enough without your child asking for costly brand-names.

item.title: 'Beautiful' rare octopus spotted on popular Welsh beach
item.description: A photographer who was enjoying a walk on a popular Welsh beach says he became "completely absorbed" after spotting an octopus.

item.title: Chelsea v Pafos, Newcastle v PSV, Juventus v Benfica, and more: Champions League – live
item.description: Below the zigzagging contrails that paint the blue Brussels sky, Christian Burgess is reflecting on the latest chapters of his extraordinary journey, those since joining Royale Union Saint‑Gilloise almost six years ago.

item.title: Australia earns global praise for economic 'soft landing'
item.description: A new report from the OECD says Australia's economy is returning to normal but remains vulnerable and lacks dynamism.

item.title: Marseille v Liverpool: Champions League – live
item.description: Marseille: Rulli, Pavard, Balerdi, Medina, Murillo, Hojbjerg, Kondogbia, Weah, Greenwood, Traore, Gouiri.

item.title: Fetal heart monitors still available online despite being banned
item.description: For expectant parents, knowing their baby's heart is beating at a healthy rate can be deeply reassuring.

item.description: SBS acknowledges the Traditional Custodians of Country and their connections and continuous care for the skies, lands and waterways throughout Australia.

item.title: Mercy review – Chris Pratt takes on AI judge Rebecca Ferguson in ingenious sci-fi thriller
item.description: The film’s ostensible target is the insidious power of AI, though the movie partakes of today’s liberal opinion doublethink, in which we all solemnly concur that AI is very worrying while not having the smallest intention of doing anything about it.

item.title: Secret love letter shows softer side of Cambridge spy ring’s alleged fifth man
item.description: It was a love letter written by one of the more important British spies of the cold war that made Tom Brass realise he had never fully known his mother.

item.title: ‘We played to 8,000 Mexicans who knew every word’: how the Whitest Boy Alive conquered the world
item.description: If you were to imagine the recent evolution of music in Europe as a series of scenes from a Where’s Wally?-style puzzle book, one bespectacled, lanky figure would pop up on almost every page.

item.title: Prue Leith leaves The Great British Bake Off
item.description: Dame Prue Leith is to leave The Great British Bake Off after almost a decade as a judge on the show.

item.title: Oldest cave painting of red claw hand could rewrite human creativity timeline
item.description: A stencilled outline of a hand found on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi is the world's oldest known cave painting, researchers say.

item.title: Coldplay help teen's campaign dream come true
item.description: A teenager's dream came true after her favourite singer serenaded her in front of thousands of people and helped raise awareness of a medical condition.

item.title: Storm brews over new F1 rules loopholes as Mercedes and Red Bull gain advantage | Giles Richards
item.description: Unveiling their new engine in Tokyo should have been a significant moment for Honda to celebrate but behind the scenes, the storied marque – as well as plenty of their Formula One rivals – are worried that a looming row over new engine regulations is threatening to overshadow the opening of the 2026 season.

item.title: EU lawmakers vote to hold up Mercosur trade agreement over legal concerns
item.description: BRUSSELS (AP) — European Union lawmakers on Wednesday voted to hold up ratification of a major free trade agreement with the Mercosur group of South American countries over concerns about the legality of the deal.

item.title: Triple J’s Hottest 100: more than 2m votes have been cast – but who will win?
item.description: Inside the offices of Australian youth broadcaster Triple J, the results of the Hottest 100 – which will be counted down on Saturday – are a closely guarded secret.

item.title: Gen Xers the new baby boomers: analysis identifies Australia’s richest landholders by generation
item.description: Gen X households now hold the most property wealth of any generation, as baby boomers downsize their homes and move more of their money into cash and retirement accounts.

item.title: I Do review – immersive hotel drama as wonderful as a real wedding day
item.description: When isn’t there big family drama in the buildup to a wedding? The nerves, the tantrums – sometimes even charges of “inappropriate” first dances.

item.title: Free holiday swimming for thousands of children
item.description: Thousands of children will be able to swim for free again this year, during the school holidays.

item.title: Nato chief urges ‘thoughtful diplomacy’ after US treasury secretary’s jibe at Denmark
item.description: Donald Trump has landed in Switzerland for the Davos global gathering as Nato’s secretary general said “thoughtful diplomacy” was the only way to deal with growing transatlantic tensions, remarks that came shortly after the US treasury secretary had dismissed Denmark as an irrelevance.

item.description: Another season, another name, another kid from Dallas.

item.title: Driving test cheating up 47% in Great Britain, prompting road safety concerns
item.description: Attempts to cheat on driving tests in England, Scotland and Wales increased by 47% in a year, figures show, raising concerns about road safety.

item.title: Significant sexual safety problem for women working in elite UK sport, says survey
item.description: There is a significant sexual safety problem for women working in elite sport in the UK, according to a survey, with 88% of respondents reporting they had been the target of at least one form of sexual misconduct in the past five years and five people (2%) saying they had been raped in work-related contexts outside the main workplace in that period.

item.title: Is listening to an audiobook as good as reading?

item.title: The transatlantic order is crumbling. Greenland is a moment of great rupture | Christopher S Chivvis
item.description: The announcement on 17 January that Washington will impose punitive tariffs of 10% to 25% on eight European allies – unless they facilitate the “complete and total purchase” of Greenland – is likely to be the death knell of the post-1945 transatlantic order.

item.description: Skies across the UK were lit up in hues of green and pink by the Northern Lights on Monday evening.

item.title: UK approves Chinese ‘mega embassy’ in London after reassurances from spy chiefs
item.description: The UK communities secretary, Steve Reed, has given permission for China to build a vast new embassy near the Tower of London after spy chiefs told him that the risks to national security could be controlled and dealt with.

item.title: King Harold coins from 1066 and Roman artefacts top UK’s 2024 treasure finds
item.description: A hoard of pennies linked to Harold II and most likely buried on the eve of battle in 1066, a rare Roman vehicle fitting, and a group of early medieval objects are among the archaeological finds and treasure discovered in Britain in 2024.

item.description: India radically tightened its rules on egg donation to make it altruistic, but that move triggered a vibrant black market for human eggs.

item.title: Valentino, designer whose gowns made royals and movie stars feel beautiful, dies at 93
item.description: MILAN (AP) — Valentino Garavani, the jet-set Italian designer whose high-glamour gowns — often in his trademark shade of “Valentino red” — were fashion show staples for nearly half a century, died Monday.

item.description: Australia, alongside the US and UK, has one of the world’s highest consumption rates of ultra-processed foods which have been linked to “multiple diet-related chronic diseases”, according to a global report of which Lawrence was a co-author.
